config.question: Why did public loyalty to the institution of slavery in the Upper South gradually decline?

choices.content: Slaves were less crucial to the region’s growing industrial sector and diversified agriculture.
Southerners there gradually accepted the idea of abolitionism.
The slaveowners had personally witnessed the brutality of slave traders.
The limited availability of slaves caused an increase in slave prices.

answer_3.response: The institution of slavery had a weaker hold on public loyalty due to the declining importance of slave labor in the Upper South. More rapid urban and industrial development than elsewhere in the South accompanied this diversification of agriculture.
